title: Kelpie Light
description: A week alone at a lighthouse. You're not alone.

scenes.title: Arrival
scenes.content:
The boat's engine dies with a wet cough.

McLeod doesn't help you unload. Just watches from the wheelhouse as you drag your duffel bag onto the slick rocks. The lighthouse looms above you, white paint peeling like old scabs.

"Radio's busted," he calls over the wind. "Has been for months. You sure about this?"

You nod. Seven days. The money's too good to refuse.

His boat putters away into the grey. The sound fades until only the waves remain, slapping against stone. Salt spray stings your face.

The lighthouse door is painted red. Rust bleeds from the hinges.

Inside, everything smells of damp wool and something else. Something sweet and rotten, like fruit left too long in the sun. The logbook sits open on a small table. The last entry is three weeks old.

*Weather holding. All well. G. Morrison.*

Your predecessor. The one who didn't come back to shore.

The stairs spiral up into darkness. Each step creaks under your weight. At the top, the great lens waits. Tonight, you'll light it for the first time.

choices.text: Explore the lighthouse keeper's quarters first
Go straight to the lamp room and test the light
Read more of the previous keeper's log entries

scenes.title: The Quarters
scenes.content:
The keeper's room is small. A narrow bed. A washbasin with brown water stains. Morrison left his things behind.

His clothes still hang in the wardrobe. Wool sweaters that smell of tobacco and brine. You run your fingers along the sleeves. The fabric is damp.

Everything here is damp.

A photograph sits on the nightstand. Morrison with a woman and two children, all gap-toothed smiles. The glass is cracked down the middle, splitting the family in half.

Under the bed, your hand finds something solid. A wooden box, carved with symbols you don't recognize. Spirals and knots that seem to shift when you're not looking directly at them.

Inside the box: shells. Dozens of them, all the same species. Small, black, iridescent. They whisper against each other when you move the box.

The sound reminds you of voices.

You close the box quickly. Set it back where you found it.

Outside, the wind picks up. The lighthouse groans like something in pain.

choices.text: Keep the shell box with you
Leave everything untouched and go to the lamp room

scenes.title: First Light
scenes.content:
The lamp room is all glass and metal. The great lens sits in the center, each piece of glass cut to catch and throw light across the dark water.

You flip the switch. Nothing.

The backup generator sits in the corner, red and silent. You pull the cord once. Twice. On the third try, it roars to life.

The lighthouse beam sweeps across the sea.

Out there, something moves in the water. Too big to be driftwood. Too purposeful to be debris.

You grab the binoculars from their hook. Through the lenses, you see it clearly.

A horse's head breaks the surface. Mane streaming like kelp. Its eyes reflect the lighthouse beam, glowing green in the darkness.

It watches you watching it.

Then it slips beneath the waves without a splash.

Your hands shake as you lower the binoculars. Seals, you tell yourself. Just seals playing in the surf.

But seals don't have manes.

The light continues its steady rotation. The generator hums. Everything is as it should be.

Except for the wet hoofprints on the rocks below.

choices.text: Go down to investigate the hoofprints
Stay in the lamp room and keep watch
Check the logbook for similar sightings

scenes.title: The Logbook
scenes.content:
You flip back through Morrison's entries. His handwriting gets shakier as the weeks progress.

*Day 12: Saw something in the water. Horse-like. Probably kelp.*

*Day 18: It came closer tonight. Definitely not kelp. Called McLeod on radio but no answer.*

*Day 24: Radio completely dead now. The thing circled the rocks for hours. I can hear it breathing.*

*Day 29: Found shells arranged in patterns on the rocks. Spirals. Like the old carvings. I think it's trying to communicate.*

*Day 33: I understand now. The shells. The patterns. It's not trying to communicate. It's counting down.*

The final entry is just one line, written in what looks like charcoal:

*It wants to come home.*

You close the book. Your tea has gone cold.

Outside, something scrapes against the lighthouse wall. Long, deliberate scratches, like fingernails on stone.

But the sound comes from too high up. Thirty feet above the highest tide.

The scraping stops.

Starts again.

Stops.

You count the scratches. Seven. Always seven.

choices.text: Go outside with a flashlight to investigate
Barricade yourself inside and wait for morning

scenes.title: The Shore
scenes.content:
The rocks are slippery with more than seawater.

Your flashlight beam catches them first. The hoofprints. They lead from the water's edge to the lighthouse door, then back again. The impressions are deep, too deep for any earthly horse.

Between the prints, shells. Hundreds of them, arranged in perfect spirals.

You kneel down. Touch one. It's warm.

The beam of your flashlight catches something else. Pale shapes in the water, just below the surface. You wade in up to your ankles.

Bones. Human bones, picked clean and white.

A ribcage. A skull with the jaw missing. Finger bones scattered like dice.

The water around your feet begins to warm. Something brushes against your leg. Soft. Like hair.

You stumble backward onto the rocks. Behind you, the lighthouse beam sweeps the sea.

In its light, you see the horse's head again. Closer now. Close enough to see that its mane isn't kelp.

It's hair. Human hair. Long and dark and streaming.

Close enough to see that its eyes aren't eyes at all.

They're holes. Empty sockets that go down and down.

It opens its mouth. Morrison's voice comes out.

choices.text: Stay and listen to what it says

scenes.title: Collecting
scenes.content:
The shells sing when you carry the box.

Not loudly. Just a whisper of sound, like wind through reeds. You set the box on the table next to the logbook and lift the lid.

The shells have rearranged themselves. They form a spiral now, each one placed with mathematical precision.

You didn't do this.

You pick up one shell. Hold it to your ear.

The ocean roars inside it, but underneath the waves, voices. Morrison's voice, calling your name.

How does he know your name?

You drop the shell. It lands point-up in the exact center of the spiral.

Outside, the lighthouse beam sweeps across the water. In its light, you see them. Dozens of horse heads bobbing in the surf. All watching the lighthouse.

All waiting.

The shells grow warm in their box. The whispers get louder.

One of the horses breaks from the group. Swims closer. Its hooves strike sparks against the underwater rocks.

It wants its shells back.

It wants you to bring them home.

scenes.title: Barricaded
scenes.content:
You drag Morrison's wardrobe against the door.

Push the table against the window. The chair goes on top. Everything you can move, you move.

The scraping starts again. Closer now. Right outside the window.

Seven scratches. Pause. Seven more.

You huddle in the corner with Morrison's photograph. The crack in the glass has spread. Now it cuts through all their faces.

The generator dies.

The lighthouse beam goes dark.

In the sudden silence, you hear breathing. Not yours. Something else. Something patient.

The door handle turns.

Impossible. You barricaded it. The wardrobe weighs two hundred pounds.

But the handle turns anyway.

The door opens with a sound like sighing.

Morrison stands in the doorway. His skin is grey-green, mottled like old seaweed. Water drips from his clothes, pooling on the floor.

"Time to go," he says.

Behind him, more figures crowd the stairs. All the lighthouse keepers who came before. All the ones who never made it home.

They're all waiting for you.

scenes.title: The Offering
scenes.content:
Morrison's voice spills from the creature's throat like water from a broken pipe.

"Come home," it says. "Come down to the deep places. We've been waiting so long."

Other voices join in. All the keepers who came before. Men and women whose bones rest in the kelp forests below.

"The light calls us," they chorus. "But we cannot climb. We cannot return. Unless..."

The horse-thing wades closer. Its hooves scrape against the submerged rocks.

"One keeper for seven years of safe passage. One life for many. The bargain holds."

You understand now. The shells. The patterns. The countdown Morrison wrote about.

Seven days. That's how long each keeper gets to decide.

You can run. Swim for the mainland when McLeod returns. Leave this place to its hunger.

Or you can walk into the water. Join the voices beneath the waves. Keep the ships safe for another seven years.

The creature extends one hoof toward you.

Its touch is surprisingly warm.

"Choose," Morrison's voice whispers.

The lighthouse beam sweeps overhead. For a moment, you see your own reflection in the dark water.

You look just like all the others.

choices.text: Take the creature's hoof and walk into the sea
Refuse and try to escape back to the lighthouse

scenes.title: Sacrifice
scenes.content:
The water is warm around your ankles. Your knees. Your waist.

The creature's hoof is solid in your hand. Real. More real than anything you've ever touched.

"Good," Morrison's voice says. "Good. Now you understand."

The other voices rise from the depths. Welcoming. Grateful.

You were always going to end up here. From the moment you took McLeod's money. From the moment you saw the job posting. Maybe from the moment you were born.

Some people are meant for the deep places.

The water reaches your chest. Your neck.

You take one last breath of salt air.

Below the surface, everything is green light and soft singing. The bones of ships rest in the sand like cathedral ruins. Fish swim through ribcages.

You settle among them. Another keeper. Another guardian.

Above, the lighthouse beam sweeps empty water.

For seven more years, no ships will founder on these rocks.

When the next keeper comes, you'll be waiting.

You'll have Morrison's voice to call with.
